occurrences.line_text: Who with that wicked shaft him wounded had,
Or that the wicked steele empoysned were:
His cruell deedes and wicked wyles did spot:
Is wicked Time, who with his scyth addrest,
Nor wicked beasts their tender buds did crop,
Busie (as seem'd) about some wicked gin:
Whom such whenas the wicked Hag did vew,
This wicked woman had a wicked sonne,
This wicked woman had a wicked sonne,
Closely the wicked flame his bowels brent,
She turnd her selfe backe to her wicked leares
Not halfe so fast the wicked Myrrha fled
Fiercely he flew vpon that wicked feend,
Now when the Beast, which by her wicked art
By their aduise, and her owne wicked wit,
A wicked Spright yfraught with fawning guile,
Of wicked Sprights did fall from happy blis;
The wicked engine through false influence,
And saw the wicked fire so furiously
Why then is Busirane with wicked hand
And freely read, what wicked felon so
Faire Amoret must dwell in wicked chaines,
His wicked bookes in hast he ouerthrew,
The wicked weapon rashly he did wrest,
And to him said, Thou wicked man, whose meed
Which punish wicked men, that walke amisse:
The barren ground was full of wicked weedes,
And wicked wordes that God and man offended:
Is wicked discord, whose small sparkes once blowen
That when the wicked feend his Lord tormented,
But wicked Time that all good thoughts doth waste,
The wicked weapon heard his wrathfull vow,
The wicked steele for mischiefe first ordained,
She through her wicked working did incense,
With that, the wicked carle the maister Smith
The wicked stroke vpon her helmet chaunst,
And of the wicked world forgotten quight,
Of that same wicked Carle, by Virgins hond;
Him from his wicked will vneath refrayned;
By wicked doome condemn'd, a wretched death to die.
Yet then likewise the wicked seede of vice
Mongst wicked men, in whom no truth she found,
And more emboldned by the wicked charmes,
The coffers of her wicked threasury;
And wicked customes of that Bridge refourmed.
Ay me (quoth she) what wicked destinie?
A man of subtill wit and wicked minde,
With these his wicked sons, and shewd his cankred hate.
The wicked shaft guyded through th'ayrie wyde,
Out of her fist the wicked weapon caught:
Fit for Adicia, there to build her wicked bowre.
To weet a wicked villaine, bold and stout,
Of euill words, and wicked sclaunders by him shed.
The wicked driftes of trayterous desynes,
The wicked stroke did wound his enemy,
To blot the same with blame, or wrest in wicked sort.
A wicked hag, and Enuy selfe excelling
From view of men, and wicked worlds disdaine.
Into this wicked world he forth was sent,
But he the more his wicked poyson forth did poure.
Who executes her wicked will, with worse despight.
And wicked customes make, those doe defame
Which had this outrage wrought with wicked hand.
Of former daies mishap, his sorrowes wicked sourse.
A wicked Monster, that his tongue doth whet
To erect this wicked custome, which I heare,
To worke by wicked treason wayes doth find,
The wretch, that hyr'd you to this wicked deed.
Nor any wicked feend, that mote offend
Where warres, and wreckes, and wicked enmitie
Hath wrought this wicked deed: doe feare away, and tell.
Vntill that, whether wicked fate so framed,
With which some wicked tongues did it backebite,
Whose wofull parents she hath wickedly fordonne.
First ill, and after ruled wickedly:
And wickedly backbite: Her name men Sclaunder call.
The traines of wit, in wickednesse woxe bold,
With his rude clawes the wicket open rent,
And now so long before the wicket fast
With which that yron wicket open flew,
And all within were pathes and alleies wide,
High on an hill, his flocke to vewen wide,
At her wide mouth: but being there withstood
And through the world of waters wide and deepe,
To all, that in the wide deepe wandring arre:
He that the wide West vnder his rule has,
Through woods and wastnesse wide him daily sought;
That long hath wandred in the Ocean wide,
For still to all the gates stood open wide,
To proue the wide report of her great Maiestee.
And full of Argus eyes their tailes dispredden wide.
In wine and oyle they wash his woundes wide,
Chattring their yron teeth, and staring wide
Departed thence, albe his woundes wide
And in another corner wide were strowne
And made wide furrowes in their fleshes fraile,
But forth she went, to seeke him far and wide.
And from the world that her discouered wide,
Raunging the forest wide on courser free,
Feare to his first amazment, staring wide
A wide way made to let forth liuing breath.
In all his wayes through this wide worldes waue,
That all the ayre with terrour filled wide,
And made wide shadow vnder his huge wast;
Wide gaped, like the griesly mouth of hell,
And from his wide deuouring ouen sent
All healed of his hurts and woundes wide,
And in his first encounter, gaping wide,
And holy water thereon sprinckled wide;
And spred his glorie through all countries wide.
Poore Orphane in the wide world scattered,
In cruell fight on lybicke Ocean wide,
She scorning both their spights, does make wide way,
They waued like a penon wide dispred,
And day and night her dores to all stand open wide.
Would from the right way seeke to draw him wide,
His force was vaine, and strooke more often wide,
Stared full wide, and threw forth sparkes of fire,
Deepe in his flesh, and opened wide a red floodgate.
In this wide Inland sea, that hight by name
Emongst wide waues set, like a litle nest,
Vnto the other side of that wide strond,
The sea is wide, and easie for to stray;
For still he traueild through wide wastfull ground,
And downe them poured through an hole full wide,
That to the gate of Hell, which gaped wide,
He brought him in. The rowme was large and wide,
They made the further shore resounden wide:
That forced him his ground to trauerse wide,
To yield wide way to his hart-thrilling brond;
Their murmuring small trompets sounden wide,
His larumbell might lowd and wide be hard,
There placed was a caudron wide and tall,
Ne vnder Sunne, that shines so wide and faire,
The bowels of wide Fraunce, a forlorne Dame,
That yet remaines his wide memoriall:
And lay strong siege about it far and wide.
All were the wounde so wide and wonderous,
Which gaping wide, to swallow them aliue,
Ne that approcheth nigh the wide descent,
In the wide waters: therefore are they hight
In the wide sea, they needes must passen by,
Of his wide Labyrinth, and then to haue them dround.
How to direct their way in darkenesse wide,
With his wide wings vpon them fiercely fly,
And oft his mother vewing his wide wound,
Of the wide aire her way does cut amaine,
Of all good Ladies through the world so wide,
And double gates it had, which opened wide,
For in the wide wombe of the world there lyes,
His feeble hart wide launched with loues cruell wound.
And the wide sea importuned long space
Where proud Encelade, whose wide nosethrils burnd
To the wide world, and let her fly alone,
The greene-wood long did walke, and wander wide
My Lord and I will search the wide forrest.
And with wide wings to beat the buxome ayre,
And many wide woundes launched through his inner parts.
And a wide wound therein (O ruefull sight)
At that wide orifice her trembling hart
The God of loue, with wings displayed wide,
Like three faire branches budding farre and wide,
Vnluckie Mayd to seeke him farre and wide,
In saluage forrests, and in deserts wide,
An hardy hart, and his wide mouth did gape
But like a wide deepe poke, downe hanging low,
And downe both sides two wide long eares did glow,
Belphebe raunging in that forrest wide,
Through the wide region of the wastfull aire,
Till that at length into that forrest wide,
But through the endlesse world did wander wide,
With filthy lockes about her scattered wide,
And all the world confound with wide vprore,
He kend it streight, and to me opened wide.
The same to all stoode alwaies open wide:
The wide kingdome of loue with Lordly sway,
Wearing a Diademe embattild wide
And glisters wide, as als' of wondrous Bath,
There also was the wide embayed Mayre,
In the wide champian of the Ocean plaine:
The time and place was blazed farre and wide;
Hath in a watry cloud displayed wide
Yet was as great and wide ere many yeares,
To weete the cause of their assemblaunce wide.
Soring through his wide Empire of the aire,
Vppon the bosse with stones, that shined wide,
And with wide glauncing words, one day she thus him proued.
Not farre away, but little wide by West,
And gaping greedy wide, did streight deuoure
And laught so loud, that all his teeth wide bare
Vppon her wide great wings, and strongly flew
He day and night doth ward both far and wide,
In perils strange, in labours long and wide;
And in his wide great mouth away her bare,
Till she recured were of those her woundes wide.
And greedy mouth, wide gaping like hell gate,
His aged wife, with many others wide:
Their thickest troups, & round about him scattreth wide.
Through widest ayre making his ydle way,
In widest Ocean she her throne does reare,
A virgin widow, whose deepe wounded mind
To me sad mayd, or rather widow sad,
Sent by their mother, who a widow was,
Being then new made widow (as befell)
The woefull widow had no meanes now left,
The widow Queene my mother, which then hight
And widowes ayd, least they should be vndone:
Through weakenesse of my widowhed, or woe:
Then this bold Tyrant, of her widowhed
And widow-like sad wimple throwne away,
Yet armes till that time did he neuer wield:
And wield the world, she claymed for her syre,
Ne none can wound the man, that does them wield.
But vnder him a gray steede did he wield,
And yield it those, that stouter could it wield:
Which his right hand vnarmed fearefully did wield.
But horse and foote knew Diamond to wield:
Like to the rod which Maias sonne doth wield,
An huge great speare, such as he wont to wield,
Which when he saw, the glaiue which he did wield
Expressing well his nature, which the same did wield.
With such his chearefull speaches he doth wield
Could wield about, that ere it were espide,
And did his yron axe so nimbly wield,
As euer wielded speare in warlike hand,
By strength was wielded without pollicie;
Gainst which me seemes this war ye wrongfully haue wielded.
A lustie knight, as euer wielded speare,
He gan to watch the wielding of his hand,
Fro[m] Guendolene his wife, though alwaies faithfull prou'd.
Who had to wife Dame Mertia the fayre,
Fiue sonnes he left begotten of one wife,
And to him gaue for wife his daughter bright,
And his faire wife, whom honest long he kept vneath.
He left his wife; money did loue disclame:
Gratious respect, thy wife shall backe be sent,
To seeke his wife, that was farre wandered:
Whereas his louely wife emongst them lay,
That not for nought his wife them loued so well,
And to his wife, that now full soundly slept,
Then to be false in loue, profest a virgine wife.
For Triamond had Canacee to wife,
Poeana takes to wife:
But to accept her to his wedded wife.
But much more aged was his wife then he,
And giues to him for wife.
Yet had refusde a God that her had sought to wife.
So faire a wife for her sonne Marinell.
That many Lords haue her to wife desired:
Being the dowry of his wife well knowne,
His wife was Isis, whom they likewise made
They slay the Soudan, driue his wife
By his bad wife, that hight Adicia,
With that his wife in friendly wise to deale,
Where soone as his proud wife of her had sight,
The wife of bold Sir Bruin, who is Lord
Gan greatly thanke his host and his good wife;
His aged wife, with many others wide:
Old Meliboe and his good wife withall
So home vnto his honest wife it bore,
That euery wight to shrowd it did constrain,
In which that wicked wight his dayes doth weare:
His dwelling is, by which no liuing wight
To be the fairest wight, that liued yit;
Then cride she out, Fye, fye, deformed wight,
Though faire as euer liuing wight was faire,
Yet neuer shew of liuing wight espyde;
For she was wondrous faire, as any liuing wight.
Most wretched wight, whom nothing might suffise,
Pardon the errour of enraged wight,
To gaze on earthly wight, that with the Night durst ride.
A fordonne wight from dore of death mote raise,
And hides for shame. What wit of mortall wight
To weet, what wight so loudly did lament.
To thinke of wight so faire, but gazing stood,
A wearie wight forwandring by the way,
The same to wight he neuer wont disclose,
Where neuer foot of liuing wight did tread,
Whose gates he found fast shut, ne liuing wight
Was neuer wight, that heard that shrilling sound,
What mortall wight could euer beare so monstrous blow?
Nor voice was heard, nor wight was seene in bowre or hall.
With all his powre, to weet, if liuing wight
And wondred at so fowle deformed wight.
And that weake captiue wight now wexed strong,
That rules mens wayes, and rules the thoughts of liuing wight.
To weet, what mister wight was so dismayd:
That cursed wight, from whom I scapt whyleare,
But I more fearefull, or more luckie wight,
Ere long they come, where that same wicked wight
And to the villein said, Thou damned wight,
Come, come away, fraile, seely, fleshly wight,
Here in this place, or any other wight,
But that same end, which euery liuing wight
So wondrous force, from hand of liuing wight;
For till that stownd could neuer wight him harme,
Ne liuing wight would haue him life behot:
The face of earth, and wayes of liuing wight,
Yet can they not warne death from wretched wight.
Leaue, ah leaue off, what euer wight thou bee,
Or earthly wight thou be, withhold this deadly howre.
To heape more vengeance on that wretched wight;
That same is Furor, cursed cruell wight,
Ne euer wight, that mote so welcome bee,
To rid a wretched man from hands of hellish wight.
An vncouth, saluage, and vnciuile wight,
But when as earthly wight they present saw,
The fairest wight that wonneth vnder skye,
But I, that am fraile flesh and earthly wight,
On earth like neuer grew, ne liuing wight
For lenger time, then that, no liuing wight
Was neuer wight, that treason of him told;
Nor wight, nor word mote passe out of the gate,
What wight she was, that Poplar braunch did hold:
And keepes in couerts close from liuing wight,
Faire Helena, the fairest liuing wight;
To be no earthly wight, but either Spright,
That could not die, yet seem'd a mortall wight,
Ne euer land beheld, ne liuing wight,
For they haue oft drawne many a wandring wight
That wight, who did not well auis'd it vew,
Right hard it was, for wight, which did it heare,
But weenedst thou what wight thee ouerthrew,
Whom when the Lady saw so faire a wight.
High time it seemed then for euery wight
Yshrowded was, and euery mortall wight
Whose prowesse paragon saw neuer liuing wight.
Nor man it is, nor other liuing wight;
That of no liuing wight he mote be found,
Then euer him before or after liuing wight.
Of mortall Syre, or other liuing wight,
For neuer wight so fast in sell could sit,
And in a rocky caue as wight forlorne,
What mister wight (said he) and how arayd?
A fairer wight did neuer Sunne behold,
Is, that she is the fairest wight aliue, I trow.
Through which it was vneath for wight to wade;
That thou hast shewed to me sinfull wight,
With heate and humour, breedes the liuing wight.
That in the same did wonne some liuing wight.
And doubted her to deeme an earthly wight,
What mister wight that was, and whence deriued,
Lightly she leaped, as a wight forlore,
But she, or such as she, that is so chaste a wight.
He seeing with that Chorle so faire a wight,
The fairest wight on ground, and most of men esteemed.
But when she looked vp, to weet, what wight
There was his wonne, ne liuing wight was seene,
As an immortall mote a mortall wight,
Then he would make himselfe a mortall wight;
To weet, what wight he was, and what his quest:
Ne suffreth he resort of liuing wight
To be a woman wight, vnwist to bee,
The fairest woman wight, that euer eye did see.
Redresse the wrong of miserable wight,
Hatefull both to him selfe, and euery wight;
Nor wight appear'd, but wastefull emptinesse,
That euery wight dismayd with darknesse sad,
Ne liuing wight she saw in all that roome,
Conueyed quite away to liuing wight vnknowen.
And falsly seekst a vertuous wight to shame?
That it could ouerreach the wisest earthly wight.
That day, the dreddest day that liuing wight
Some newborne wight ye would him surely weene:
Which Triamond had worne, vnwares to wight,
For saluage wight, and thereto well agreed
From wight vnworthie of so noble meed.
That dreadfull seem'd to euery liuing wight,
Ne euer was there wight to me more deare
Ne wight him to attend, or way to guide,
What mister wight it was that so did plaine?
To whom thus aunswer'd was: Ah wretched wight
So on a day vnweeting vnto wight,
She looking backe, espies that griesly wight
Now freed from feare and danger of that dismall wight.
For wofull wight, chose out a gloomy glade,
But like strange wight, whom he had seene no where,
What mister wight he was, or what he ment:
Or wrath of cruell wight on thee ywrake?
If wrathfull wight, then fowle rebuke and shame
Hath done this wrong, to wreake on worthlesse wight
With misregard, that some rash witted wight,
Awayting to entrap the warelesse wight,
There worshipped of euery liuing wight;
The which, more eath it were for mortall wight,
Cares not what euils hap to wretched wight;
In solitary silence far from wight,
But promist him, what euer wight she weare,
For neuer wight so euill did or thought,
Of force, ne fraud in wight was to be found:
In Ioues eternall house, vnwist of wight,
Or whether his owne hand, or whether other wight?
Ne wight with him but onely Talus went.
What mister wight (quoth he) and how far hence
For neuer wight he lets to passe that way,
For wight, against his powre them selues to reare:
Ne he his mouth would open vnto wight,
Ne wight with him for his assistance went,
Ne yet to any other wight on ground,
For neuer yet was wight so well aware,
First rings his siluer Bell t'each sleepy wight,
To be the greatest, and the grauest wight,
Ne wight but onely Talus with him went,
What Tygre, or what other saluage wight
Full dreadfull wight he was, as euer went
Most sacred wight, most debonayre and free,
All solitarie without liuing wight;
For wretched woman, miserable wight,
The which hast me, of all most wretched wight,
That he had red her Riddle, which no wight
An aged wight, wayfaring all alone,
For shame he weend a sleeping wight to wound.
Rather then let my selfe of wight be stroken,
For armed knight a wight vnarm'd to wrong.
Into the land of Faerie, where no wight
What manner wight he was, and how yclad,
Yet was he courteous still to euery wight,
Ere they were well aware of liuing wight,
That he should be so sterne to stranger wight:
A stranger wight in place, her plaint she stayd,
Cannot redressed be by liuing wight.
In such a saluage wight, of brutish kynd,
Small praise to proue your powre on wight so weake.
Infixeth in the name of noble wight:
Ne wight with him on that aduenture went,
He had behynd him left that saluage wight,
Of euery wight, that were not too infest,
Said then the one of them; Where is that wight,
The more it is admir'd of many a wight,
She was borne free, not bound to any wight,
As no whit dreading any liuing wight;
Who her admiring as some heauenly wight,
But Calidore, though no lesse sory wight,
Both his estate, and loue from skill of any wight.
From view of liuing wight, and couered ouer:
Not sparing wight, ne leauing any balke,
Out quenched, leaues no skill nor difference of wight.
Ne wight he found, to whom he might complaine,
Ne wight he found, of whom he might inquire;
Whereof her wombe vnwist to wight was fraught,
Into the emptie fields, where liuing wight
That neuer more he mote endammadge wight
All liuing wightes in might of magicke spell:
Can call out of the bodies of fraile wightes:
That here wex old in sleepe, whiles wicked wights
Banisht from liuing wights, our wearie dayes we waste.
They all beholding worldly wights in place,
With which bare wretched wights he dayly clad,
And looking downe, saw many damned wights,
They brought forth Giants and such dreadfull wights,
Of fowle misshapen wights, of which some were
What now is left of miserable wights,
We mortall wights, whose liues and fortunes bee
To succour wretched wights, whom we captiued see.
Whom of all liuing wights she loued best.
There was it iudged by those worthie wights,
Whose office was, against all manner wights
And then all liuing wights, soone as they see
Else should afflicted wights oftimes despeire.
Ne scarse wyld beasts durst come, there was this wights abode.
The noblest wights with notable defame:
Emongst wild beasts and woods, from lawes of men exilde.
Sith earst into this forrest wild I came.
Pursew her steps, through wild vnknowen wood;
Wouen with antickes and wild Imagery:
Sterne was their looke, like wild amazed steares,
But like wild beasts lurking in loathsome den,
And after wild, it should to her remaine:
Some like wild Bores late rouzd out of the brakes;
Vntill they came in vew of those wild beasts:
Deadly engored of a great wild Bore,
That euen the wild beast shall dy in starued den.
Of some wild beast, which with her arrowes keene
Seemeth that such wild woods should far expell
In this wild forrest wandring all alone,
He fine would dight; sometimes the squirell wild
As two wild Boares together grapling go,
In these wild woods, as was her wonted ioy,
Therefore he wild her doe away all dread;
In great displeasure, wild a Capias
That wild the damzell rise; the day did now expyre.
Charm'd those wild-beasts, that rag'd with furie mad.
The danger hid, the place vnknowne and wilde,
Nought there vnder heau'ns wilde hollownesse,
And that wilde Champion wayting her besyde:
And flaming mouthes of steedes vnwonted wilde
Led her away into a forrest wilde,
He noursled vp in life and manners wilde,
To wander, where wilde fortune would me lead,
As wont ye knights to seeke aduentures wilde,
In this wilde forrest, where no pleasure is,
Do lay away, and all wilde beastes do rest,
Then of wilde beastes if she had chased beene:
For that wilde Bore, the which him once annoyd,
That raungd abroad to seeke aduentures wilde,
At wilde aduenture, like a forlorne weft,
And many wilde woodmen, which robbe and rend
Wrought with wilde Antickes, which their follies playd,
It was to weet a wilde and saluage man,
For other food then that wilde forrest beares,
